Topic.Title: No Voice and Data same time

Message.Msg: Media reports that it's an antenna issue which is inaccurate. I believe they decided to go this way to improve battery life. If you run voice on CDMA and data on lte at same time, both chips are drawing power simultaneously. There's a conscious decision here and not a technology shortcoming on apple or qcoms part. I'd guess that soon enough voice will be supported on LTE and then you'll have voice and data without killing battery on this same phone. Probably a smart move by Apple.

Message.Title: Apple’s dual 100 acre solar farms revealed in aerial photos
Message.Msg: Apple’s dual 100 acre solar farms revealed in aerial photos by Madison E. Rowe • September 15, 2012 • Alternative Energy, Business, Solar Energy • 0 Comments With a multi-billion dollar budget that keeps Apple afloat, it is no doubt the software giant’s ecological footprint is probably a big one. But the company is looking to ease that footprint when a massive solar farm in the U.S. goes online. New photos captured from the sky show that Apple’s sprawling solar farm, which will reportedly power its North Carolina data centre, is almost finished. The aerial images were captured by WCNC-TV and published by GigaOm this week. The farm is located adjacent to Apple’s data centre in Maiden, North Carolina, that powers iCloud. AppleInsidercom reports that the 100-acre solar farm will be the largest of its kind in the United States once it becomes operational. The website goes on to note that the photos show only one of the solar farms that Apple is planning. A second facility, also 100 acres, will also be located a few miles away. Together, the solar facilities will reportedly supply 84 million kilowatt-hours of clean, renewable energy annually. AppleInsider says the solar array will allow the data center to use 100 percent renewable energy by the end of this year.

Message.Title: IPhone 5 is a Flop. There is no Buzz. No excitement.
Message.Msg: No one I know who has Galaxy SIII is even considering IP5. People who have IP4s are under 2 year contract and will not break contract for IP5. People who didn't get 4s and waited for IP5 are disappointed and will not get IP5. That means the only people who are going to get IP5 are those who have IP4 and are die hard Apple fans. That means the the number of new IP5 owners will be less than current IP4 owners since many of them will jump ship to Galaxy SIII, GNote 2, or Lumina or HTC. IP5 is definitely less technically sophisticated and functionally useful phone compared to other phones in the same class. The only way IP5 sales will increase is to have sales of other phones decrease. That is not happening. Total sales numbers of IP5 will most certainly be disappointing. You cannot defy mathematics. There is only limited number of pool of buyers and every phone gets piece of the pie. IP5 is not "wow" enough to attract undecided buyer over GNote 2. It's a flop.

Topic.Title: one out of every 5 apple phones i see has a cracked screen enjoy no gorilla glass.

Message.Msg: you are too lazy and stupid to do something as easy as a search on the internet to verify some facts before posting your mumbo jumbo. i don't think you have the neurons to trade, invest let alone make any money. you have the LOSER sign hanging on you. wear it proudly Phone 5 To Have Corning Gorilla Glass by Radu Tyrsina, 06 March, 2012 4 inShare Did you think that Apple was one of the most secretive companies in the Silicon Valley? So did we; so the next slip of the tongue from Apple's PR team comes as a nice surprise. When explaining how Apple creates, or supports about a half of million jobs across the US, the official information includes: "Corning employees in Kentucky and New York who create the majority of the glass for iPhone." So far, the partnership between the Cupertino-based company and Corning has been merely a speculation. Analysts believed that the iPhones' Gorilla Glass was made by Corning, but there was no confirmation from either of the companies involved. Last year, Apple failed to include the company from New York on its list of suppliers. Even now, the information is scarce, as the Gorilla Glass is not actually mentioned. Also the phrasing - "the majority of the glass for iPhone" - leaves room for interpretation, on the actual volume of shipments. Not to mention the fact that the rest of the Gorilla Glass screens, on other iPhones, must come from a different supplier. So, Apple does a good job at being even more mysterious, when disclosing information, than when it conceals it.

Message.Title: Apple ... It's About Time for China Mobile ...
Message.Msg: With Apple's new iPhone 5 just being announced to the world, it's about as good a time as any to revisit one of the biggest carrier opportunities in front of the company and the device: China Mobile. That's a lot of subscribers This one carrier has been one of the most glaring omissions in Apple's carrier lineup thus far, primarily due to unique homegrown network standards that the carrier uses, TD-SCDMA for 3G, and TD-LTE for 4G. In the meantime, Apple has brought on its two smaller rivals, China Unicom (NYS: CHU) and China Telecom (NYS: CHA) , as official iPhone carriers. Smaller may be something of an understatement, because China Mobile's subscriber base dwarfs the other two combined, with 688 million mobile subscribers at the end of July. That's more than double the other two carriers combined, as well as more than twice the entire U.S. population of about 315 million.
